The rolls was nothing special. I thought the avocado looked kinda old on top of the Dragon Roll so far i haven't had any stomach aches! lol. The only one i really liked was the Ki Ki Roll which was known to be VERY SPICY as stated in the menu but it wasn't THAT spicy. I miss Sushi Rika! 

However, my sister ordered the MoMo Roll which was very good. 

The service was good, the only set back was the waitress forgot my Mango Spider Roll. Maybe i shouldn't have said anything because i could have save myself $15 bucks for an OK special roll. I don't really care about the price but i thought the flavors and presentation was not worth $15 bucks.

i doubt i will come back to Sushi Rock or maybe ill try the other locations. However, thank you for having the Colts and Patriots game on their flat screen TV's!!! Too bad Colts lost :(
author: Carol Y.

description:
Went there on a Saturday for an early dinner because we happened to be tooling around in Chinatown. The place was empty when we got there but filled up about half way by the time we left. It was LOUD even with it half full.

The service was totally lacking. There were two waitresses who were so flat and just didn't seem to care. We had to keep flagging them down for things because they wouldn't come over.

The miso soup and tea were lukewarm. The udon broth tasted like beef broth that came straight out of a can. The rolls we ordered all tasted the same.  I COULDN'T TASTE THE FISH. Who knows how fresh the fish was. Scary.

And the bathrooms were filthy. I generally think the cleanliness of the bathroom says a lot; there is a direct correlation between the cleanliness of the bathroom and the cleanliness of the kitchen.
author: Joody B.

description: The restaurant offers good sushi, it is not the best but it tastes better than it looks. We ate roll n roll and lion king roll and they were great! They also give you miso soup salad and rice for free with your order. The lemon chicken had a great sauce but the chicken was just meh..
author: Xaxa X.

description: This place was great.  The staff was attentive and gave excellent recommendations.  Would suggest to anyone.
author: John K.

description:
Went with friends at night after a party so half of us were still full resulting in only the other half eating. The waiter was really rude and said to our faces that only half us were ordering.

Then when we got our food he gave us two orders of fried bananas when we only ordered one so we told him that we didn't want it. We could hear him dropping the plate in the kitchen from where we were sitting.
The ice cream that came with the extra fried banana was taken back by into the kitchen then given to my other friend who ordered ice cream.

Also, the other waiters and waitresses came out and were staring at us the whole time and whispering among themselves, they didn't even try to hide it. They were just straight up staring at us a few feet away.

The food was completely overpriced as well. 

WILL NEVER GO THERE AGAIN and will DEFINITELY never recommend going there. I'd steer clear of this place and just keep on walking to find another restaurant with cheaper food and friendlier service.
author: Alexa C.

description:
Only rated a "one" because you can't rate "zero." Though, in all fairness, the beer was reasonably cold (but the miso was maybe luke-warm)

A semi-quiet Sunday afternoon,  well-after the lunch "rush" and before the onset of dinner. Overall, maybe a half dozen tables were taken with a few groups. 

The two of of us ordered a simple bento box (two rolls and a shirmp tempura for her), a chirashi (sashimi over rice for me) and one more sushi roll and large Kirin for the table. The miso and the beer arrived in a semi-reasonable time, though the sushi roll and the chirashi were no where to be seen. We proceeded to sit for a good half hour while the bento box and rice were picked through (intentionally slowly) and eventually finished. At about the same pace, tables on the either side of us had received their food and finished well before the bento box was done (as my other half kept "attempting to wait" while I got my food).

Finally, as we're long-since beyond frustrated and ready to leave, the chirashi showed up on the table (though the other sushi roll still no where to be seen). So, we cancelled the rest of the order and closed out. Next time, we'll just look to spend our money somewhere else. I'd HATE to think of what this place would be like if they were actually busy.
author: Russell V.

description:
I spent a lovely afternoon shopping in Chinatown and just wanted a quick snack since I'd be eating dinner in another few hours. I had a craving for sushi so I stopped in, and boy am I glad I did!

I was immediately greeted by a friendly hostess who seated me with a glass of water, miso soup, and a seaweed & cucumber salad - so delicious and a great start to my meal (and all free of course)!  I was trying to decide between a few different sushi rolls so I told my waitress about my struggle and she quickly and enthusiastically recommended the T.T. Roll. So delicious! Spicy and crunchy and tuna (my fave!).  

Other than having to wave down the waitress to get more water, the staff were friendly and attentive.  I will definitely eat here again and would recommend it to anyone looking for good, cheap sushi.
author: Tay A.

description:
The tuna sashimi was fresh, but the rolls were kind of strange. None of them were cold. We got take out, but we're just around the corner, and it was a late night at the office, but still. I don't like warm sushi. At least make it room temp!

The delivery took a while, too. We ordered a bunch of stuff, but it didn't seem like the right quantities either. Over all, it was a less than satisfactory experience and I think there's much better (especially for the price) to be had in the city.
author: christine c.

description:
What can you expect from a chain? Mediocre food and service. It's a good spot to hit up for drinks before a night out. They have loud music and a big selection of drinks. 

I give it 3 stars for the happy hour, which is 1/2 drinks from 3-6:30. After a few drinks, the food starts tasting a little better. Hell, I have been here about 5 times...it's like Taco Bell...you want to stay away but something tells you that it's not so bad.
author: johanna a.

description: Second sushi place that was close to the Hotel. I felt the waitress was pushy with the specials and didn't know what tobiko was.. They're fish eggs ( i looked it up on google ).. Anyway, they serve you complimentary miso soup for starters and green-tea ice cream as dessert. The sushi was ok.. Had the garlic spider roll and felt kind of nauseous afterwards. There's probably better places out there with nicer waitresses.
author: Daisy P.

description:
My favorite thing about Sushi Rock is HAPPY HOUR!  (3:30-5:30)

Appetizers are 25% off and drinks are 50% off!  ALL DRINKS!  Its insanity.

The sushi is four out of five stars and the house sake is DELICIOUS!

The service is very fast and the staff is extremely polite.

One of the top 5 sushi places in SF for SURE!
author: Brandon A.

description:
It's... pretty gross. We had some delivery for a late night at the office, and it was like crappy chinese takeover version of japanese food. Really not much to say about it. It wasn't fresh, wasn't seasoned well, the tempura was limp and the miso tasted instant-package-made. 

Stay away.
author: Fiona S.

description: Came here once for takeout, which was great, so decided to sit in for a full dinner. I was met with complimentary miso and seaweed salad, both delicious, then had some very good quality fresh oysters and awesome rolls that had the same high quality as before. I think this place is great and will be back often!
author: Geoff O.

description: Really good veggie sushi. Very nice croquettes with katsu sauce. The staff are very aware of vegetarian diets and will advise miso soup contains fish stock etc automatically if you mention you are veggie. They offer an alternative with the veggie sushi platter of extra sushi.
author: Simon H.

description: My family and I have been going to this restaurant since we moved to the Nob Hill neighborhood. The service are really nice to the customers and the food that they make is fantastic. They also give you free ice cream with any available flavor of your choice. The happy hour is also a great deal to go there. The price is about average. Overall, I recommend you try this place for newcomers that want to experience sushi in San Francisco.
author: Jordan D.

description:
Went for lunch and had the happy lunch box: chicken teriyaki, beef teriyaki, and california roll. They start you of with miso soup and a seaweed salad to share. Perfect amount of food for a $10 lunch including tax and tip. 

Went back for dinner and had the 3-item combo (more choices during dinner): chicken teriyaki, sake sashimi (+$1) and teriyaki sea bass. AMAZING. the sea bass was tender and melt-in-your-mouth delicious.. the chicken was super flavorful. Next time I'll try the oyster katsu. To start, they gave us miso soup and the seaweed salad. We also ordered hamachi sashimi (very fresh), a philly roll, a tokyo roll, and a spicy scallop salad roll. The spicy scallop salad roll worried me at first because I didn't really get the "salad" part.. After eating, I still don't get it, but there was a huge piece of scallop in each bite! All that food, a large asahi, and a cocktail came out to $66. (I used a $25 coupon from restaurant.com though so it came out to $41.) Definitely coming back :)
author: Kimberly S.

description:
After experiencing some great Japanese food in the area I decided to give Sushi Rock a try....

Right as I sat down they served water, seaweed and cucumber salad, and miso soup. The seaweed salad was like typical seaweed you would by at whole foods with cucumber in vinegar. The miso soup was not very warm at all and nothing really special.

I ordered the bento box and was disappointed. The tempura did not seem freshly made. The Teriyaki Chicken was bland. The sushi was really just okay. 

The service was fast and this felt kind of like a chain/fast japanese food. An alrite place for a quick lunch perhaps if you are in a hurry but certainly not the place to have a nice dinner.

Its a bit expensive, and close by is Nara sushi/Japanese which is not as expensive really and soooo much better.
author: Julian I.

description:
This place is OK.
Ordered some sushi and sake- both reasonably priced and came out fast.

Only beef was friends ordered Bento Boxes and they came out a good 15 minutes before my Sushi. They pretty much finished and then my food came out.

Other than that- pretty good. Had much better sushi but this place wasn;t bad.
author: Matt R.

description:
Meh. Just like pretty much all the other Yelpers.

The rolls we got all tasted the same...bland. The only reason it gets an extra star is because the green tea ice cream sample at the end.

What made the experience over-the-top horrible was the service!! I can't believe that our waiter took 20-25 minutes of us sitting there staring out the window to finally come over and give us the check. At least we had something to look at........
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I'm a little mixed on this place. I like how they give  you free miso soup and cucumber salad and green tea ice cream at the end of the meal, but I was there last week and the service was slow and the green tea ice cream was OLD! Yuck!

The food is only mediocre, but the price is low and they are open late.

The staff is slow, but friendly, and the hostess was very attentive.

The rolls are sub-par, but is you just want to get sushi and don't care much about the quality, it's an ok place.

I would go back, but it's not my first choice.
author: Tina C.

description:
Wow... I am surprised by all the negative comments, since I have been here 3 times, twice for lunch and once for dinner and only experienced good service and decent sushi!  The portions were large, the price was good and the selection was great as well.
I think anyone who orders sushi delivery shouldn't be able to comment on anything! It's like buying sushi at the grocery store!
author: D F.

description: Sushi was decent, chicken teriyaki was delicious. Was a decent place, nothing overly special though.
author: Aren P.

description: Ordered food from here during a late night at work with a group of coworkers. I felt that the food was so-so. I really did not enjoy the mango tuna roll, but the phoenix roll was alright. Food arrived in about an hour. What was cool though was we were able to order online via Yelp! Thanks yelp for making my life less complicated :)
author: Konnie H.

description: Decent, not expensive, good stop if your tour of the city puts you in Chinatown at lunch.  We ordered four rolls, the roll-n-roll was best.  Free small scoop of ice cream after meal really hit the spot.
author: John F.

description:
I actually come here a lot, mostly because I live right by the place.  I noticed a lot of reviews say bad service, and I don't get it. Whenever I go there, salad and soup is brought out right when you sit down, you order, sushi comes fast, and right when you're done, here comes the ice cream.  

The sushi is pretty average and reminds me of good old, cheap college food, so it doesn't get 4 stars.
author: Lainey D.

description: Food was good but nothing special. Staff could be friendlier and mire attentive. Came here with a friend and we were basically the only ones there and got almost no service or attention, tsk the staff decided to stop their conversion. Will not come back.
author: Joji V.

description:
i heard so so reviews about this place from friends, but i was looking for sushi in chinatown and ended up here. 

I like the location, the second story location overlooks Chinatown right on grant street, which i liked. It was a hot day the day I went, so when i came in i ask the waiter if i can turn on the fan and he did, which i thought was nice.

i ordered a few rolls, wasn't anything crazy, just ALRIGHT. but the roll that was interesting was the duck roll, which i forgot what its called but it was interesting to try but not delicious oranything.

BUT i must say, their beef teriyaki was sooo moist and soft. I APPROVE!! Old man can eat it without his dentures type of soft. 

I forgot to mention, they served us house cucumber and seaweed salad, it wasn't that great, kind of chewy and plastic-like. 

The Tea though was really good! Tasted like popcorn and it had little popcorn pieces in them, or what seems like it was.

The service was good too, he kept refilling our waters, on point. He also hooked me up with the bento box happy hour price too, cause it just past.

i'd come back.
author: Tam T.

description:
Stopped at a Japanese restaurant while in town for the Chinese New Year's parade.  It was cold and rainy, so this venue was a welcome escape from the weather.

The best part was the 50% off alcohol during their happy hour - so a small hot house sake was less than $2!!!  We ordered several hot sakes, and enjoyed every last drop.

The food was definitely the two star part of this review.  It sufficed because we were hungry and cold, but I wouldn't go out of my way at all to eat here.

Service was fast and helpful.

Restrooms were interesting - full of graffiti.
author: Jonathan S.

description: One of those places that has been around forever but you've never tried.  We finally tried it and it was okay.  Haven't been back since there are places I like better but it was okay.
author: Suz L.

description: Although located in Chinatown, I would not consider it authentic at all.  Sushi was fresh and really good - honestly, probably the best I have had in a long time.  The establishment was clean with good service.  I have it three stars because it is essentially what I would get at my hometown sushi joint.
author: Anu S.

description:
All I can say is "meh" about my overall experience.

I ordered the Una-Ten Roll, because it had all the ingredients I normally like.  It was a small, sad, and bland roll.  It really didn't do anything for me.  As soon as me and my friend sat down, I ordered everything I wanted: sake, miso, and a roll.  My roll was brought out first but my drink and my miso didnt come for another couple minutes, and same thing with my friends entree being brought before the soup and beverage.

We weren't checked on at all by the wait staff during our meal but our water glasses did get refilled.  The staff was really inattentive, and there was only one other person in the restaurant.

One thing that is noteworthy of this restaurant is a larger menu, which was nice to see.  It was kind of overwhelming to make a selection.  What was really impressive is that Curries are served at Sushi Rock (only Yellow Curries, no red or green.)  My friend ordered the Chicken Curry, and I felt disappointed with my roll, I wished I ordered the Curry instead because it was so delicious.  Sad when a sushi restaurant has better curry than sushi, though, isnt it?

The place otherwise was clean, bright, and the atmosphere seemed like it would still be just as nice even with more patrons.  I don't think with all the sushi options in San Francisco, however, that I will ever go back... I am still on a quest for a more memorable sushi location that will make me crave a unique SF Sushi Experience!
author: Jenna B.

description:
NO!!!!!


just don't. Can I give half star here? 

Sushi was dry, not authentic, fish wasn't fresh, udon were gooey, soup was tasteless, think the Kikkoman was refilled with some cheap soya sauce, chicken teriyaki had chicken fats pendulums (LOL) around every piece of them..

toilets were dirty. Don't be fooled by the man who I reckon was actually a Japanese dude. He probably isn't a chef, probably worked as mechanic in Toyota and decided hey let's rock a sushi!
author: Shirley L.

description:
GOOD place for Tourists. We went to Sushi Rock for my friends birthday last weekend, and they were great with big parties. The service was quick and they kindly broke up the check into groups of 4 for us.

The food isn't that good. If you are looking for a decent sushi dinner this isn't the place. It wasn't terrible, but as a sushi snob I wouldn't come here for a nice dinner. But if you want to get together with a bunch of friends, this is the right place.
author: James M.

description: This place definitely exceeded my expectations.  After getting turned away from a half empty Akikko on a Tuesday night because we didn't have reservations, we ventured up the street and satisfied out Japanese food craving here.  At first look it seems a little run down, but the food and service were both excellent.  I loved how we were greeted with Miso Soup and seaweed salad before even ordering drinks, which of course was complimentary.  The free ice cream at the end was also a nice touch.  I would definitely recommend this place for a casual dinner in Chinatown.
author: Dan S.

description:
I went to Sushi Rock with a large group of colleagues and we were sat right away with no wait - and as others have said, we were served seaweed salad and miso. Both were average, but nice to gnaw on while we waited.  Even as a lover of choice and creative rolls, I was overwhelmed by the menu BOOK - literally, like four pages of sushi possibilities!  

I had the responsibility of ordering for the group, so I just randomly picked a wide assortment of sashimi, nigiri, and special rolls.  The quality of the fish was good, not great - i.e. this is the quality you find at most sushi restaurants, but not the quality when you bite into the fish and scream OH MY GOD THAT'S GOOD!  The sashimi was cut thick and large (get your minds out of the gutter) - typically that's awesome, but these were almost too thick to get a nice flavor out of the fish.  

The service was attentive and we had a great time.  Overall, a decent sushi joint, but not one to go out of your way for or if you expect a great sushi experience.  I will say - we all left stuffed and the price was great!
author: Dustin F.

description: This was awful. I ordered a number of different rolls, spent $50 and had sushi that was straight up Safeway quality. Really, really bland rice with old fish. Will never, ever go back. If I want decent, affordable sushi Tokyo Express is just a few blocks away.
author: Diana S.

description:
We knew better than to try to find good sushi in Chinatown. Maybe it's possible but why not go for some dim sum instead? Well, we arrived hungry and with the taste for sushi. 

Not much to say about Sushi Rock other than it fills the empty space. Smelled strongly of Pinesol or some other cleaning agent when we walked in the door. Ordered California Roll which lacked the expected cucumber. They were only so-so.

My husband ordered the Golden Gate Roll. Again...just mediocre. 

Not much to say about this ho-hum place.
author: Anne-Michelle E.

description:
I came here last month with my boyfriend, and I don't really remember much but the attentive service and the giant clam meat. I ordered the sashimi combo, and ehhh, it was okay. We also ordered some mango roll and a bento box. Let me tell you folks, that I left kind of hungry. 

+1 star for free icecream!!!!

Parking there sucks since it was a Saturday night. 

In conclusion, I would probably not come back here because it's not worth the time to find parking for their food. Sorry Sushi Rock, but you didn't rock my socks off!
author: Sandy T.

description:
Came here for time and convenience for lunch.  It's located on the edge of Chinatown by all the "jewelers" between St Mary's Square and the Ritz.  
It's definitely a tourist spot as almost all the other diners were out of towners.  Windows above the street level afford the opportunity to do some people watching from our table.
You'll get comped seaweed salad and miso soup to start, scoops of ice cream to finish.
They got some decent and unique rolls like the mango spider roll.  Not bad.
author: Glen G.

description: I was in Chinatown to meet an old friend, who chose this restaurant.  When I stood at the entrance area I would have turned around but for the fact my friend was already sitting down.  I normally avoid Chinatown restaurants because of sanitary conditions or rather the lack of.  Everything in this place needed to be deep-cleaned.  It is a shame that this is known as a Japanese restaurant.  I travel to Japan often where the food is superb and everything is extremely clean.  This place is opposite of that.  When I talked with the waitress (from China) in Mandarin, she knew nothing about Japanese food.  We ordered nothing raw of course (Sashimi used in Sushi must be extremely fresh and kept in the cleanest environment, not here) but even Tempura Lunch Box was not eatable.   The waitress was not surprised that I hardly touched my food.  I doubt she will eat anything at this place.  Sad.
author: LC S.

description:
This place is best for Happy Hour because it's when you are going to get the best deal.   You can easily get out of this place buzzed on half off sake and beer and full on 25% off  appetizers.  For happy hour, I don't think I have ever walked out of her spending more then $50 for 2 people.  I love their Squid Shioyaki and their Grace Roll is unbeliev!!!  Mmm... this is making me hungry!  

The reason they get 3 stars is the service is SUPER SLOW, and when I am trying to get my happy hour on and there's a time limit, you need to stop by often.  Also, their bathrooms are Disgusting!  Not Castro repulsive, but really really gross.  I refuse to give any restaurant a good rating if your bathrooms make me have to throw up the amazing food i just ate.  

My advice:  Use the bathroom somewhere else, bring hand sanitizer, and go to sushi rock between 3:30-6:30 Monday thru Friday!
author: Brandy B.

description: Got the sashimi lunch special and a glass of sake for $20 including tip.   Not bad for lunch in Union Square, but if I was in the mood for sushi again I'd probably go elsewhere.
author: Joyce J.

description:
Sushi Rock, I love you.  No, you are not the best, most authentic sushi I have ever had in my life.  That would be Sushi on the Run in Los Gatos.  But that's in Los Gatos, and you are a mere hop, skip, and a jump away.  You even encourage me to be lazy by delivering my favorite rolls to me any time after 5 PM with only a $20 order minimum.  You give me extra miso soup sometimes, too.

You seem to think I eat a lot for one person, though, because you tend to include at least 3 pairs of chopsticks.  That's okay because I hoard them, who ever remembers to buy chopsticks? Not me.

You ARE great sushi from my experience in San Francisco.  When I'm in the mood for some unauthentic sushi (creative rolls) you fit the bill perfectly.  My favorite is the Waye Roll with its crazy pink nori wrap, tuna, cucumber, fish egg, and tempura crispies tucked inside.  Potentially my favorite roll in the whole world.  Your tamago nigiri is yummy, too.

The katsu donburi is excellent, and I can usually turn the leftovers into at least 2 extra meals.  That's a STEAL!

I like eating in at your location, too, when I have visitors.  The free cucumber & seaweed salad is really good.  The service is friendly, and the view of Chinatown below makes for good people-watching.

So, Sushi Rock, I just wanted to thank you for being you, and I'll ignore the haters forever.  Even if my mom is included in those haters.
author: Mary O.

description: Good lunch sushi and ambience. Not many places open for sushi during daytime so that is a plus. and definitely want to come back for happy hour! One of only serving happy hour. Sushi was good and chef guided to the daily fish which was very fresh. Japanese beers were warm only reaon it doesnt get 5 stars!  Dont want to have a bud light at a sushi joint:) Nothing against bud light:)
author: Keith C.

description:
Its too bad the service here makes me give one star.  The food is pretty decent for the FiDi area in SF.  The servers are rude, and rush you out event though the place is not even full to its capacity.  They tried to take our food away from us twice until we asked them to leave us alone and that we would tell them when we were done.

Over terrible experience.  The lunch bento box is a great choice but when you can't sit down and enjoy it in peace whats the use?  I will never return here again...terrible lunch experience.
author: Samantha S.

description: Wait Staff was really nice, almost makes me want to bump it up to 4 just because of how awesome they are. The rolls were small and 3/5 rolls were okay. I can't even remember what we ordered because with the exception of one, the rest sort of tasted the same. They gave us a free soup of ice cream at the end. But I think I might go back just for the awesome service and give it another try.
author: Tiff W.

description: Tried to use the GoPago to get 20 worth of free food, but it was togo only.  Either they should have said something or I didn't look at it properly.  Food didn't seem fresh, but I didn't get sick, so that has to be mean something.
author: A L.

description: This is not quality sushi.  The fish does not taste fresh and all the crabmeat is fake - if there is any real crabmeat it is not evident.  That's really all that needs to be said for a sushi restaurant.  I would not recommend it.
author: Tony B.

description: I think this place is better for Happy Hour than for sushi. The happy hour is 50% off ALL drinks. This allows me to try some fancy new kinds of sake without breaking the bank. The highlight of our meal was that my friend got a Sapporo for ony $1.75 (normally $3.50.) Nice! Other than that, I was not impressed with the food or the service. Oh, and the prices are pretty high when it's not happy hour.
author: Laura L.

description:
This place looks like the place to go to for people who have no idea where the hell to eat sushi... or what sushi is... kind of like a "tourist" sushi spot, if you will. Their food is decent, though. Not horrible (I don't think they really deserved those bottom of the barrel 1 stars), but not anything quite exceptional. 

Our server was a really nice guy... the restaurant has big windows so he gets distracted watching people's cars get towed in the afternoon, but other than that, really nice and great service.

They have a good happy hour and good lunch deals ($7.50 for bento boxes if you like those). A real upside to this place is that they're open during the odd "in between meals hours" and on Sundays when all other sushi joints are closed... I've come to realize that these restaurants that stay open all the time have sushi of slightly lower quality, but it's nothing to throw a tantrum about. Would I come here again? Hmm probably if I was in the Union Square area and had a restaurant.com certificate again, haha. If you're a sushi snob, turn around and walk away... but if you're just looking for a casual, clean place with decent food and great window views to people-watch, this place is great!
author: Anna V.

description:
I came here for lunch one day and they have a great deal on lunch boxes.  $7.95 gets you three items, a bowl of rice and miso soup.  I had the gyoza, chicken katsu, and the CA roll. Everything was pretty standard.  it's hard to judge a sushi restaurant based solely on their bento box and not on their fish.  Nothing too special about this place but nothing I can complain about.

The server was nice because he let me charge my phone in the side room and placed a napkin on top to protect it.  Nice that he even let me charge my phone! Aside from that highlight, I can't say that I'll come back unless I want sushi and I'm in chinatown.
author: Helen V.

description:
We tried this place at the suggestion of a friend, a local, who goes here for happy hour.  We found the restaurant mediocre made worse by poor service.

The sushi rolls were fairly small for the price paid.  i'm not sure what everyone else got, but I got the tamago roll which was done fine - though it's not exactly the most difficult roll to put together.  The egg rolls were pretty good, but I did not know it had crab meat (or imitation crab meat) in it until after I bit into it.  I wish I would have known earlier as allergies are questionable, and I typically do not eat meat.

Service was pretty spotty.  I think there was at least a 20 to 30 minute period where we did not see our waitress.  Our appetizer was brought out about 5 minutes AFTER we had FINISHED our rolls that was meant to be for dinner.  There was no apology or explanation or anything.  We also never received the tea we ordered.  It must also have gotten lost in the ether.

If we were not visiting I might return to try their happy hour or lunch specials which seemed to be a good value.  But, simply as a visitor of the city, I would probably not return nor would I recommend it to people with only a short time in the city like us.
author: Keopu R.

description: Pretty good sushi from a sushi chain restaurant.  Nothing spectacular except for the big windows for people watching.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
After the giants world series parade, my friends and I were in search of a location to grab a bite and watch the champions receive the key. WE finally walked all the way to chinatown to get away from the crowd.  

It was really hot in the restaurant! I felt like there wasn't any air conditioning.  I know San Francisco rarely see's the sun, but on occasional days like these, air conditioning is so important!

My friends and I each ordered the lunch special.  It was about 7.50 and you can pick three items from a list.  I got the chicken teriyaki, gyoza and california roll.  It comes with rice and miso soup.  I think it was a good portion of food.  I wasn't stuffed but I was a good full.I thought the food was just average.  I can't say much about the bento box.

My friends needed to charge their iphones, the waiter was nice enough to lt them plug in their phones in a private room.

I thought the food was average.  I would go back if looking for sushi in chinatown, but would never go out of my for it.
author: Joanne H.

description:
Decent place with decent sushi.

Convenient because you can walk around and work off that food afterwards..

Prices are average.

Good customer service.

Not on my top sushi fav list though.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Disgusting. I will never go here again, even if my life depended on it. I had the most horrible sushi that wasn't fresh and was barely edible. Even after a fun night of happy hour in town (when I'm usually the most hungry and in a pleasant mood) I couldn't bring myself to eat any of the rolls or the udon I ordered. 

Here's a snippet of a conversation I had with a friend:

me:  what did we eat at sushi rock?
the one with the cream cheese sushi
 
Andrew:  I think it was called the horrible piece of crap roll
Actually i just remembered because the name is ridiculous
It was called the "Sexy Roll"

SAVE YOUR MONEY FOR MIKAKU RIGHT DOWN THE STREET!!
author: Jenny T.

description: Just Ok.  Convenient to China town.  Good place for kids.
author: S C.

description:
I just ordered from this place off of the internet and the estimated delivery was at least 45 minutes.  Imagine my surprise when it showed up a mere 20 minutes later, to my apartment door, and the delivery guy even had a smile on his face!  I was already impressed.  

Now as far as the food, I tried the Sushi Rock on Polk, and it was pretty mediocre so I wasn't expecting anything mind blowing.  And I suppose it wasn't, but it was actually pretty good!  I got the Rock Dinner Special, and the tuna sashimi pieces were fresh and pretty big!  Everything else was good as well.  Definitely a fan, and from now on, I'm sticking to the Pine St. location for delivery.
author: Laura C.

description: Average to below-average sushi. A step above pre-made Safeway sushi. The rolls were small and the fish didn't seem fresh. The avocado was especially not fresh and had those little brown spots on it... The only reason we went was because it was cheap, and even cheaper since we had a coupon by using an app. Maybe I went on an off day? (Saturday around 1pm.) Maybe it's worth you trying out for yourself? I won't go back though.
author: C D.

description: Came here about 4 pm on a Friday, it was empty except for two other tables. It had a good view to do some people watching  over Chinatown. Ordered tempura green beans and lemon chicken, and chirashi. The green beans were delicious, but took a while to come(20 or so minutes). And a few minutes after that they brought my lemon chicken. My bf did not get his chirashi for another few minutes, so basically the timing was off throughout the whole meal, which resulted in some cold food for me while I tried to split my time between the green beans and the chicken. My lemon chicken was delish, not too sweet, and my bf said his chirashi was good as well.
author: Bear A.

description:
Still lovin' sushi rock.  I got the hamachi carpacio with jalapeno and the house cold noodles.  Good stuff.  I wanted the spicy salmon skin handroll too, but did not want to over eat lunch.

Great service and good price.
author: Jaime O.

description: Great sushi, excellent technique, and good quality rice and nori. The service was slow and disjointed, not professional at all.most worrisome thought he servers seems like they really couldn't care less. I guess the price you pay in the heart of the tourist area ie close to one of the gates to China Town.
author: Stephen M.

description:
Basically on a whim,  my gf and I decided to get a room at the intercontintental down in Soma to really enjoy the July 4th holiday.  Upon arrival we realized we needed a bit of stomach padding for the evenings "events".  Sushi was a good choice, so we ended up ordering out from here.

I'm not sure if the food is better there or what but I have to put it at a solid mediocre.  The spicy tuna roll was... well acceptable.  The fish was good enough, but I think they skimped on the spicy sauce a bit cause htere just wasn't much flavor (come on now... that's the cheap part guys).

Dragon roll was pretty good, but then again we didn't even finish it... does htat say something?  I woudlnt get tempura to go either... not here or any other chinese resteraunt for that matter.  Save that for in house and stick wiht a salad.

This place just had too low of an impact on me to say more than that.  NExt time I"ll try eating in.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Kanpai! Happy Hour!

Good prices on food and drink.  I was pleasantly surprised by the selection and quality of their food.  

The walk up/down Pine Street will tone up those glutes!
author: Lisa M.

description: So friendly, great prices and tasty sushi! Wish I would have known about this place last night. Delicious!
author: Tiffany J.

description:
The fact that I'm giving this place 2 stars despite the fact that...

- We used a $25 gift certificate for a $60 bill
- Service was excellent
- They gave us free miso soup and lychee/coffee ice cream
- Ambiance was upbeat and lively

...must say a lot about the quality of the sushi here. 

Am I wrong to order the "Sexy Roll" and expect something luscious, mouth-watering, and...well...sexy? Sadly, the roll was far from sexy; it actually looked flaccid. You can only imagine my disappointment when I got a droopy, cold california roll topped with stale-tasting salmon, completely coated in Kraft singles. Yes, Kraft singles, those processed cheese squares we all use to find in our lunch boxes as kids. They literally decided to murder my appetite and eliminate all meaning of the word "sexy" by putting that garbage on top of my roll. Not cool, Sushi Rock, not cool.

Two friends and I split only 3 1/2 rolls and we still could not force ourselves to finish everything on the table. I felt like we were on Fear Factor or something...like we were contestants being forced to finish plate after plate of really, really bad food. 

If you have a choice, don't eat here, no matter how "sexy" they promise their rolls to be.
author: Joseph F.

description:
The food is decent. The service was quite slow!
I ordered my bento box lunch special.. It took 10 mins.. I also ordered the yakitori.. which took 30 mins... which is only an appetizer
author: Jan P.

description:
So, Thursday turns out to be the best day of the year in San Jose and I'm dying to go for a drive. Thankfully I had chosen the highway without the 15 mile back up. I pick up my lady and head to the city. After watching a gorgeous sunset on the beach at Crissy fields we are hungry for sushi. We drive around checking places out and by the time I wipe out the droid and hit up yelp we're downtown. Rock Sushi's in the area. I hadn't eaten since breakfast. We go.

On the outskirts, if not in Chinatown, the place has a low ceiling but it adds to the chicness had a couple of TVs that had the lakers game and I don't think my girl saw me watching It was around 9pm and only one large party was in there. We were seated swiftly by a nice girl. we promptly received glasses of ice water followed by 2 bowls of miso soup and a nicely cucumber salad. All quite tasty. I will say the menu is probably too big, even for a sushi spot but the rock box is an excellent choice. I ordered salmon teriyaki with unagi and tempura. My lady, tuna, shrimp tempura and avocado roll. This came with a bowl of rice and salad. Tempura came hot and light and crispy and delicious. Unagi had a way too much glaze and it made the eel very sweet. The salmon, however, was very fresh and was grilled so the skin was nice and crispy and it had a smooth smoky flavor. I would get that again. We also got a couple of rolls that were mediocre. Cant really remember more that that about them. All and all very satisfying and for the price in the city not bad.

Pluses: 
Reduced Sodium Kikkomon on every table. 
Salmon Teriyaki
Free sherbet
reasonable prices

Minuses:
Forgettable sushi rolls
locations not great
author: Jamal F.

description:
The food here is decent, but it wasn't great.  Maybe I just didn't order the right items.  A big plus is that they served a free cucumber and seaweed appetizer before your meal, and a free ice cream afterwards.  The service was also good and they filled our water and took our orders pretty quickly (although it wasn't very crowded late on a Thursday night).  I also like that they take restaurant.com certificates because the rolls here are a little bit more expensive that the sushi places that I usually go to.  I just wish that I have known about this before I went because I have a ton of these than I need to use!

I ordered the rock bento box and chose the tempura, oyster katsu, and sea bass teriyaki for $11.99.  The tempura was decent, but the other two items weren't very good.  There were only 2 pieces of fried oysters and while they weren't bad, they didn't taste particular fresh.  There were 3 thin slices of sea bass, and it had a peculiar flavor.  I usually like sea bass, but the fish that they served here tasted particularly fishy and not good.  It may have been the teriyaki sauce, but I can't say for sure.  All in all, the portions for the bento box were also quite small. 

It's probably worth another visit to see how their rolls are, but next time, I'll be sure to come prepared with a restaurant.com certificate.
author: Tyler C.

description: Great miso soup!! One of the best I've tasted since I left Hawai'i. Has extensive menu at pretty reasonable prices. I recommend the tuna sashimi or the rock box!!! And they give you free mango ice-cream!!!
author: Octavia C.

description:
Sushi Rock, 

Thank you for delivering in a quick and timely manner to the lobby of my office (you said 45mins, but it came in 20mins). Although I have tasted better quality sushi, you're still A-OK in my book. You made my long night at the office just a little more bearable. 

xoxo, 
Angela
author: Angela L.

description:
Old fish. Not appetizing at all. I ordered a negi hamachi roll, got a tekka maki instead. rainbow roll wasn't impressive and it was way too expensive for what I got. Try another place.

Not to mention that had to be the saltiest miso soup I have EVER had!

ew, just ew
author: Angelic S.

description: This was the worst service I have ever gotten. Last night my cousin & I entered around 9pm. They sat us & gave us water half filled. As I looked at my glass, I saw the imprint of lips on my glass. I had red lipstick on & the imprint was clear but noticeable. As the night proceeded, they took about 20 minutes to take our order. They sat a number of parties & even brought then the miso soup & seaweed salad, while we received nothing. I even had to ask to for the soup & when the waitress brought it over, she slammed it on the table & walked away. I'm very disappointed in their service & will never return or recommend anyone there ever again.
author: Renee T.

description:
I got introduced to this place bout 2  and a half years ago.  Sushi Rock seemed to have a wide variety of items including vegetarian and vegan sushi rolls.  At the time I was going there, I was a vegetarian but I still had cravings for sushi.  This place did the trick.  After 10 months of no meat or fish I couldnt take it anymore and went back to eating fish.  BOY was my first sushi meal TASTY!  

I think my favorite is smoked salmon... yum! getting hungry just thinking about it!

I'm not a fan of the parking around there.  It's a pain in the rear end to try to find parking out there.  

The service has been good for the most part but I have experienced some bad service there a couple of times.  I figure they were busy and perhaps those servers were just 'off'?

Anywho,  I'd go back there again.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This seems to be a popular "touristy" place for sushi restaurants.  There are many signs that point me to this conclusion: tons of sushi choices, fairly affordable prices, and tons of combos to suit the tastes of everyone's needs.

But hey, who's complaining here?  The sushi were generous portions and the rolls were very affordable.  For 3 people, we thought we ordered enough to fit everyone's needs, but we ended up ordering too much.  We ordered pretty standard stuff (katsu, chicken teriyaki, and spicy tuna rolls), so I can't comment on the specifics (since it's pretty standard).

But if you're looking for a cheap, place that will meet everyone's sushi needs, this probably will be a good choice that won't bring a lot of fuss (unless you're a sushi snob).
author: John K.

description:
Came here with the BF for dinner and I must say if you get a certificate from restaurant.com for this place, it's totally worth it! They gave us free miso soup and edamame beans which is a plus and the rolls we got were pretty good.  The fish seemed pretty fresh and there was one roll that contained mango in it that tasted very unique and surprisingly very good.  Although this place doesn't stand out as being especially amazing, I would definitely eat here again (especially if I had a cert from restaurant.com)

PS it was really funny that they were playing K-pop and not J-pop =p just an observation, hehe
author: Ann H.

description:
I live right by sushi rock and I used to go here for the convenience factor...until at least I found an eyelash in my cucumber salad!! Since then I've avoided this restaurant at all cost!! Plus I think the service is mediocre.
I would rather hop on a bus to Japan town or head to the Richmond for other sushi options...
author: Jen L.

description:
I'm not sure why this place has mixed reviews. The service here was fantastic and the food was delicious. The servers were very helpful and very attentive, and even realized when their service wasn't amazing and made up for it. One time that we ate there, they were a little slow due to a large party and gave us free ice cream to make up for it. I'd say that's paying attention to the customer!

It's good food, good service in a good location. I would definitely recommend eating there.
author: Frank D.

description:
I'm incredibly surprised at how low the ratings are for this place.  I've been eating here for a couple of years already and when I first started coming two years ago, the ratings were great.  I now feel like after they started doing the restaurant.com promotions (and hey I use it everytime too so I'm not complaining but...) their ratings have just gone down from 4.5 stars to only 3 stars!!  So apparently on top of being cheap (as I am), people are also incredibly harsh. 

I honestly feel like this is a great restaurant.  My entire company (we're at 600 California Street right at the heart of the financial district) loves coming here.  Okay, so not many of us are Japanese or Sushi experts but we enjoy what they have.  Most people don't even use the discount, only us lowly admins (hehe) but they still seem to enjoy it.  Also, my family & friends that I bring here also always enjoy it.  I've never had a complaint and I have honestly given this place a ton of business.  People I know always want to come back.  Even without the discount, the price for sushi here is still incredibly reasonable.

Although the claim is that the sushi is not as authentic as it should be, I think it's always delicious and fresh.  Whenever I use the $25 gift certificate and spend $35, we always get a TON of food.  $10 each for two people for a sushi dinner including tip is pretty damn good if you ask me!!  That's if you're in Japan, NYC, or even just at the mall!!  It honestly can't get any better than that.

Okay, so for the actual update review.  My friend and I came here last night for dinner since we were going to the ballet and wanted a great and fast place to eat before going.  

We got :
FREE miso soup & cucumber/seaweed salad (not all places do this so I'm always happy that they do)
Philadelphia roll, Golden Gate roll, and Rock N'Roll
Scallop & prawn salad
Deep fried banana & 2 scoops of ice cream (also complimentary!!)

The rolls were good!  Soup & salad always good.  The scallap/prawn salad was excellent but my friend really didn't like it.  I scarfed it up.  The banana dessert is always so delicious with the ice cream.  I really did enjoy myself and I was so full my dress barely fit.  My only complaint was that I was terribly uncomfortable at the ballet & a bit sleepy after eating so much food.

However, I will absolutely NOT complain about the $11.00 I spent that evening.  Our bill came up to $22.11 with tax & tip after the restaurant.com $25 gift certificate I bought for $2!!!!  I'm sorry but that's freakin unbelievable!  On top of all that, they still give the freebies... the soup, salad, and ice cream were all complimentary and I'm sure we're not the only ones they do this for!!  Every time I have come they always do this. 

I know that people enjoy coming here because every month the gift certificates sell out for this restaurant over every other restaurant on that website for the financial district AND chinatown area.  I'm saddened by those people that probably eat here frequently and take advantage of this offer every month yet still give them a mediocre rating.  I honestly believe that just on SERVICE alone, they get an excellent review.  The staff is always incredibly accomodating and attentive.  The owner always looks stressed out (I can imagine why) but he is still always really nice and friendly.

Okay and yes they do play a little Miley Cyrus.  I did chuckle when I heard her song playing but honestly, is that truly a reflection of the food & service?  Are you really that much of an anti-Miley fanatic that it's that big of a deal for you to live through or completely hate on a great business just for that?  Maybe grow up just a little bit... 

Anyway, on top of all this... it's at a great spot.  It's one of those restaurants where it's very open and the windows go all around the restaurant so it's nice to people watch while you're eating your sushi.  Even though it's not a swanky place.  Trust me, this is great especially for tourists.  Have a little taste of the Chinatown scene and watch from your small table while you sip your complimentary miso soup.
author: Kay R.

description:
Nothing outstanding, nothing bad:

1. Dynamite roll (spicy hamachi) - good
2. Veggie roll - VERY good, lots of veggies and tasted fresh (would recommend)
3. Spicy scallop hand roll - very good, scallops soft and sauce had perfect of amount of heat
4. Gyoza (fried) - solid
5. Tonkatsu - PASS-- too thin for my liking, I prefer thicker cuts of meat, seemed like we got more "fry" than pork--these people are CHEAP!
7. Ice cream (ordered green tea but they gave us mango) - SMALL PORTION! It was probably the size of 2 to-go salsa cups--I guess you get what you pay for ($1.50), but it was good nonetheless (good thing I wasn't craving ice cream at the time, otherwise I'd be PISSED).

Summary:
* Decent food 
* Prices too high for what you get = portions on the smaller side
* Rolls are on the better side of average
* FREE DELIVERY (will probably order here again because I'm a sucker for sushi BROUGHT TO MY DOOR), but wouldn't come into the restaurant unless it was to check out the happy hour...
author: Kristine W.

description:
I come here with my parents because our family usually gets a 15% discount from eating here all the time. It's one and a half blocks away from where my parents live so it's convenient to come here.
All-time favorites:
Mango Spider Roll
Seabass Terriyaki
Tofu Terriyaki
Seaweed Salad-- Thanks Em!

Old favorites:
Curry Chicken Katsu-where did the chicken katsu go?
Deep fried star- a little dry?
author: Goldie L.

description: Our go-to sushi spot, mostly since we live in the area.  Prices are certainly reasonable, particularly if you incorporate their happy hour deals, and I love that they automatically give you a miso soup, salad, and ice cream with each meal.  Great service.
author: Audrey P.

description: I had no idea this place was not only good, but don't rip you off either. They have an awesome lunch menu that starts around $6-7. I would stick to the Sushi Rock combo menu. I ordered the seabass, tempura, and for a $1 more, tuna sashimi on the side. I was on lunch break, and needed to eat badly. In under 10 mins, I got a piping hot box of everything with rice, salad, and miso soup. The seabass was grilled perfectly, the tempura batter was nice and light, and tuna was firm and tasty. The service is fast and friendly; the server even brought me water while I figured out what I wanted for takeout.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I'm right across the street in a hotel, so I've been ordering from this place pretty often. Their menu is pretty extensive, especially as far as the sushi goes. I'm not a fan of raw fish - duh, you ask, so why order from a SUSHI place? Well, they do have other food there too. The Rock Box meals are a DEAL ($11.95) and come with TONS of food - if you're okay with one of your choices to most likely be teriyaki. I've also had all of their udon choices, which are also good on a cold San Francisco night. The potato croquette "appetizer" is HUGE - 4 croquettes and katsu sauce. The prices aren't bad at all, but the staff I have encountered on the phone or when I go to pick up take out really aren't too friendly.

The music there is meh. It seems like it's just the normal popular stuff they play on the radio. The place really does have people in there every night, even considering how the economy is these days. It's actually pretty surprising.

They do have free delivery with a $20 minimum purchase, which is a plus.
author: Kim K.

description: Awsome temaki!  killer specialty rolls.  I loved that they start you with misso and seaweed salad the second you sit down.
author: Jed S.

description: I walked in on a HOT FRINKIN DAY and had a beer then proceed to order for a mango crispy crab roll had complimentary mi so soup and cucumber seaweed salad. As I was still hungry I order a tako ginger and then a tuna tartar all so good!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: Im not a sushi snob and I loved it got stuffed in 20 dollars. The rock box is plenty expected less and over ordered. But I was very happy with this cheap place.
author: Brittany S.

description:
To the waitress and waiters that had to deal with me, I'm so sorry.

The happy hour (on a saturday!!!) sake bombs were too much for me.
I love the sushi here.. Its cheap, affordable and so yummy. 

I am def. coming back
author: Victoria Y.

description:
Just because Sushi is in the name, do not be fooled in to thinking that is what is best.  

After several years on this esteemed planet, there are a few things that I have picked up in deciphering the not so eloquent language of "Sushi, sushi, sushi."  If the word "sushi" is in the name, be on alert.

My friends and I stumbled our way over here after an intense day of studying our effing brains out.  Seriously.  We were this close to popping a fuse, on that would not be mended by super glue.  My hair was falling out, I was showering every other day, you could hide something from my by putting it under my toothbrush, usual law school final exam behavior.

Upon entering this eatery that is nestled in Chinatown (and thus desperate for business as the tourist destination is wont to be), we were transported to another place.  In here, law school doesn't exit.  Stress melts away as the bustling waitresses showed us our seats.  We were brought complementary cucumber seaweed salad, complementary soup, and at the end, complementary ice cream!  For a income-deprived student, that is GOLD!

I got the bento box with salmon shioyaki, saba shioyaki and california rolls.  It had salad.  Yum.  And fruit.  Yes.  I scarfed down the whole thing and licked my fingers afterwards.  Well.  No.

The fish was delicately broiled/grilled.  The surface was slightly caramelized while the insides were steaming and tender and succulent.  I abhor dry fish.  I loved this fish.

The price was excellent and it wasn't even lunch or some happy hour time.  About $13.
author: Christina C.

description:
Tuesday: January 16, 2007. 
8:25pm, light rain and wet.  
Dinner with my drinking gal, a co-worker (the b-day girl) and her sister.

After stuffing ourselves at Calzone's, my drinking gal and I decided head on out to Sushi Rock.  The restaurant was empty, just a few people getting their grub on.  Since I was having my second dinner, I just ordered tuna nigiri and a bowl of rice.  Miso soup and cucumber/seaweed salad were both complimentary along with the tea.  The Others ordered special rolls to share including T.T. Roll (spicy tuna, tempura), a scallop with unagi roll, and several hand rolls.  

My tuna nigiri and rice came out very quickly.  Overall, the food wasn't bad, but wasn't great either.  I probably won't be seen at this location anytime soon because it's out of the way for me and my food experience here isn't that memorable. 

OMFG!?!?!?  Their website is so f'ing slow and because of that, they just lost another STAR.  However, I do like that they have Happy Hour everyday from 3:30p - 6:30p -- specials include 50% off drinks and 25% off appetizers :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
If I could give a negative score I would give it a -30.

If you're in San Francisco, have 4 days off from life and looking to get food poisioning please go to Sushi Rock.  I will also make a review of the hospital I spent 7 hours in as well.  

I was in San Fran for a week for work and decided to walk around and get a feel for the city.  Upon walking through chinatown I noticed this cool looking restaurant (sushi rock) and decided to try it out.  I was the only person at the sushi bar which was cool but the aura of the place seemed a bit weird.  I ordered about 30 dollars worth of sushi (day and night, california rolls and philadelphia rolls)  I'm expecting I got sick on the day and night rolls, but who knows.  

Anyway, it's October and I was in San Fran in August.  Prior to Sushi Rock, sushi was my fav food.  I haven't eaten sushi since.

Thanks for ruining my fav food SushiRock...  I should send you my hospital bill along with my food receipt for reimbursement.

Do not go here.  Send your worst enemy (ok don't do that, no one deserves as much pain as I had)
author: Henry B.

description:
Came here with my roommates because we had a restaurant.com gift certificate!

Overall, the food was pretty average.  We got the sashimi combination and 3 rolls to share.  Food wasn't bad or great, just okay.  I wouldn't usually complain about this but the prices were pretty steep!  So for the price, I'd say it's not worth coming here.  There are much better and more reasonably priced sushi restaurants nearby.

I would however, give 5 stars for the service if I could!  When our sashimi came, there was some weird looking octopus on it and we asked if we could switch it out for something else, and they did!  We also got free miso soup, seaweed salad, and ice cream!  The waitress also chased us down to give my friend back the lipgloss that she left at the table!

Overall: average food, steep prices, excellent service!
author: Shintau L.

description: I was pleasently surprised with the service and quality of sushi at a place with such a name as sushi rock. Is this a trend? Sushi Rock, Sushi Zone... tackiest name  = best sushi?  Anyway, I loved how they brought the little salad and miso soup to start off with for free. In the end, they also gave us ice cream - for free! It was fabulous. Everyone enjoyed their sushi, as it was fresh and well prepared.
author: Mark S.

description:
Just ok.  This place is better for bento boxes and cooked items.  You want real, bomb-ass sushi?  This place ain't it.

Having said that.....they have a three item lunch special bento box that hit the spot for me.
author: Kiki G.

description:
Decent sushi in a good area with nice prices.

Popped in here just before midday with a couple of co-workers. Got a seat no problem, and after reading the review here, expected pretty average sushi.

Ordered the "G" lunch special ($14) with the NY roll (but it had avocado in it!) and some sushi. It was delicious, and very filing. Free miso soup came with it, and walked out $19 down and happy.
author: Joseph T.

description: Went on a Saturday night. No wait. Complementary misoshiru soup and cucumber seaweed salad were great. We had three rolls for two people which was more than enough. The Ki Ki roll (spicy scallops) was my favorite. The Volcano roll (spicy salmon) was also good. Both were very fresh.  The T.T. roll (spicy tuna) was my least favorite. It was more heavily battered than I like tempura to be. They also gave two small complementary ice creams. Not sure what flavors but they were great. This place is a mix between your neighborhood hole-in-the-wall and your trendy hot spot. All in all, I enjoyed it.
author: Matt F.

description:
I'm sad to report that I have to rate this place 2 stars. I went to the Polk street one and loved it. But then I went to the one (I think it's on Sutter) right by Notre Dame, I was very very dissappointed.

We ordered so much food mostly because we were looking for the taste we found at the Polk Street outlet but didn't find it. What's worse than being full and dissatisfied? 

I hope to one day be proven wrong.
author: Vanessa G.

description:
I find this place a hit or miss. Fresh oysters are great (I recommend calling in advance because when I ordered at 3:30pm on a weekend, I was told they were out.).

Sushi is so-so. The udon is yummy.

Service is hit or miss as well.

Atmosphere is good. They play good music, and you can watch sports on the tv.

They also have really good sake.
author: Wendy L.

description:
If you don't mind seeing peeling wall papers while eating then have a seat by their sushi bar area. 

The bar needs some cleaning as dusts gather by their lamps and vases. 

The prep area needs to be clean period. Sorry but it doesn't. 

The food tastes ok and the quality is good. I would definitely recommend this for a quick lunch.

Nothing fancy, not too expensive and not cheap as well. It fits right for the quality of the food and the service they give. The sushi selection is alright. 

Again, the place needs to be cleaned. It does not have to go with the Chinatown street scene theme- "old and dirty".
author: Ron T.

description:
We honestly could not even finish our meal from Sushi Rock because it was so awful.  The california roll had MAYO in it.  I seriously hate it when places do that!  Another roll smelled so fishy that I almost, well, it was hard to get down.  It seemed overpriced, but I might just think that because it was a waste to us.  

Apparently, the one on Polk has a better reputation.  A friend swears it is good, so I might try that one, give it one more chance.  But, I do not recommend Sushi Rock on Pine.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I like Sushi Rock a lot. The reason why I only gave them 3 stars is because they don't really have very many salads on their menu. I am a huge salad fan!! I can go into what I "think" they should offer on their menu in regards to salads, but alas, I will refrain....

Here are some of my favorites from the Sushi Rock Menu:

Daegi -- Spicy Tuna, Scalop & Tobiko Roll
Poki Roll -- Spicy Tuna, Tobiko & Green Onion
Oshinko  -- Pickled Radish Roll
Hamachi Negi -- Yellow Tail, Green Onion & Tobiko Roll

The wakame salad and the house cucumber and seaweed salad that they serve as you are seated are delicious. Sushi Rock has a relatively large Sake selection, which is great for me because really enjoy Sake with my sushi. The prices are very reasonable and the service is good as well.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Review is for their Happy Hour.  Prices are definitely right and the appetizers were not bad at all.  

It's always good when Happy Hour Places have not ONLY good drinks but good food TOO.  And it definitely tastes better with the Happy Hour Discount.  

So be sure to come and try their appetizers.  Their FULL appetizer menu is available.  The only downside is that they do not seem to have a full bar.  Looks like your drink options are Beer, Sake and Soju Cocktails.  

HAPPY HOURS DEETS: 3:30p - 6:30p Daily
50% off Drinks
25% off Appetizers
author: Mark W.

description:
3.5 stars.  Came here for lunch today with my coworkers.  When we got there at 12:30, plenty of tables were still available... I don't know if it's that the majority of workers in the financial district don't head up a block (towards Chinatown) to look for food, or if 12:30pm was just early.  

The food is not bad, but nothing special.  The Happy Lunch Box for $7.95 is a decent value.  The next time I'm looking for Japanese food close by work, I'll be coming here.  Sushi was mediocre, but still replaces Tokyo Express on my eats list.
author: Randall L.

description:
So this may not have the best deco but I do like it's on the second floor that gives an elevation feel. I always like places that are not on the ground floor, be it 2nd, 15th floor, or the basement, it always gives a different experience.

Food wise, the Matthew roll was a bit small but good deep fried ones. Spider roll was with pretty good deep fried batter, not greasy but a bit crunchy yet soft meat even the crab was a bit skinny. Dynamic roll was quite spicy that burned through my tongue for a few minutes. NY roll was okay and basic.

The best part was the complimentary ice-cream, like a bite or 2 of green tea that was bold, strong and deep taste, while the mango was sweet, light and uplifting like sugar cane.

The price is reasonable, for 2 people it's about 43 dollars.
author: T L.

description: After a nice chinatown experience, we capped it off by stopping here before heading home... It was a nice little place and the servers were really polite. However, they were severely delayed on bringing the food out together and bringing it in an orderly fashion. How did this happen? No idea. I just know that the food quality DID make up for their mistake - the food was pretty great and I loved my bento box! I will definitely go back.
author: Terry B.

description:
I had lunch here with my old boss on her company's dime, but I'd say it was okay if i didn't have to pay. The lunch box special is priced pretty well, but some of the selections are pretty weak. I got the ton-katsu, tempura, and california rolls. The ton-katsu was decent, but a little dry; the tempura was borderline gross; but the california roll was pretty good - but it's a california roll, how hard is that? also kind of annoying was that there was no sauce for the tempura or any place to the soy sauce for the sushi on the bento plate they served it up on.

but i might be willing to check out their sushi some time based on the california roll, but there are other places that are probably better and cheaper not too far from here.

The one plus is that it seems to be able to accomodate larger parties... but that's because it's always empty.
author: Bernie L.

description:
I have given this place several tries. It is fine if you are having a bee or two and order a California role, or perhaps an Avocado roll. For anything else, for the same price, go somewhere else. The place smelled today like rotten fish, the service was slow, and the food was terrible. The salmon was fatty, not fresh, and sliced so thick. I actually had to spit out a piece of it, and really, I can eat anything. 

Of course the beer was fine. But the place left such a bad taste in our mouths that we had to leave and relocate.

The nice touch is miso soup and a seaweed salad. But today really solidified, that I will not order anything other than beer and vegetable rolls from this place.
author: Danielle V.

description:
YUCK!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This place is absolutely disgusting. Every thing on the menu was terrible. The worst roll we ordered was some scallop/cheese roll. I am pretty sure the cheese they used was Kraft singles. SICK! 

Speaking of sick, my friend and I got FOOD POISONING from eating here for two straight days after.  Its a good place to go if you feel like you need to louse five pounds and spend a few days in bed. 

Never going back.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Nice!  I am a fan because of their Happy Hour!

I only came for drinks but you get a cucumber salad and miso soup just for coming in, on the house... Although I didn't even try the food because I wanted to drink, it was nice...   

I was also glad they had Dark Japanese Beer like Guiness!
author: Limzer L.

description:
I'm a fan!

So many things to rave about:
-the extensive menu with unique rolls
-the tempura green beans
-the spider hand rolls
-the mango/tuna rolls
-the "rock"in' music, i.e. Lil Wayne, Katy Perry, and Jordin Sparks
-the validated parking
-the big screen tvs (FX, NBA, etc)

The food is fresh and the service is good.
author: Misha F.

description:
3.75 stars

This place is pretty cheap when you go as a group and especially if you have a restaurant.com certificate. I used to come here often over the summer with my friends and co-workers for lunch or dinner. My fave is you can get 3 items for $8 or less (in group+coupon) for lunch, and they're really generous with their portions. Each order also comes with seaweed--mmm seaweed. I'd probably come here more often if I had time during lunch but yea it's pretty decent compared to other Japanese places in the area.
author: Natalie G.

description:
Came here last night for dinner with some friends and the only thing that pops into my mind was, pleasantly suprised. 

To be honest with you im quite skeptical of non-traditional japanese restaurants with the deep friedness sushi and such. But when we ordered, I tried some and they were pretty delicious. I must say that I have become a fan of Sushi Rock for its decent take on the non-traditional japanese food. 

Tips and pointers:
-Get the T.T. Roll, very good
-Prices are midrange to high
-Portions for rolls are surprisingly large
-Parking is non existent, and if its in a lot its pricey
-View is cool, you get to overlook chinatown while you eat
-Location is cool

[APPROVED]
author: Eric T.

description:
Sushi's cool. Music sucks. 

The food is good, there's a pretty decent variety of rolls and I love that you automatically get a bowl of miso soup and cucumber seaweed salad the moment you sit down. 

Every time I've gone there, I could describe their service as being either very attentive or them wanting to kick my ass our of the restaurant asap. Just about every server that passed our table asked if we were finished with our plates when there was still a significant amount of food on them and we gave no hints of being ready to leave. 

Oh, and I could do without the looped dance remixes of fall out boy and rihanna. They should either change their name or their music.
author: Anne Marie S.

description:
I found this restaurant on restaurant.com, its a web site that allows you to purchase gift certificates at a discount. 
Parking is best in St. Mary's garage, they will validate for you. 

Upon sitting down we were delivered 2 complementary sake bombs and a cucumber salad. The food was decent, I've def had better sushi, but this was great for what it was. 

There are pages of sake to choose from and pages of rolls for under $6. 

Service is wonderful and the environment is very welcoming. 

I went with my gf and we were surprised with a complementary ice cream dish at the end of our meal with chopsticks holding up a sign that read "Love Forever" :P cute.
author: Gavin L.

description:
Had a few rolls here just two days ago.  While the quality of fish was good, I found that they had some major issues with their rice...  
Rice to be used with sushi traditionally needs to be short grain and seasoned with a sugar, salt, and rice wine vineger mixture.  As far as I could tell, the rice used in their rolls was plain from a rice cooker without additional seasoning, very lame for a RESTAURANT.
In any case, the quality of fish saved the dish that day.  If you were to go, I hope you're as lucky as I was to walk in on a day when their fish is fresh~
author: J D.

description:
While walking up Grant St. today, I happened upon the newly opened Sushi Rock # 2!  Now listen, I crave sushi just about every day, and today was no exception, so I decided to take a rain check on the dim sum I was planning to eat (http://www.yelp.com/biz/o__w2Hufu0Bdc_hKfi8OYg?hrid=_H6wtIhSKDjoGuoMIm3GyA) and to check out this place instead. 

I noticed that there were some groups of what looked like tourist families eating here, but it was still open and airy. I should mention that it was also around 3 pm, so any lunch crowd that this place might have was gone (which is good, 'cause I really didn't want to be seen inhaling hella sushi by some hot FiDi dudes, especially when I look like crap).  This Sushi Rock is also right on the corner of Pine and Grant streets, and is on a second level and has windows that look right over  the intersection, so it's great for people-watching.

I was promptly seated and given a menu, as well as  complimentary miso and seaweed salad (both of which weren't that great),  They have flat screen TVs showing sitcoms like "Small Wonder" (yay!) and "The Nanny" (lame!), and they also kept some hyper-ass trance music playing in the background (which I feel has a similar affect to fast-food colors, it just kinda rushes you a bit).  My waiter was very nice and attentive but not too in-my-face, and their tuna and Philedelphia rolls were excellent!  They were very fresh, with huge chunks tuna and salmon.  

I've been looking for a place in the Financial District (or nearby) that's a couple of notches above the "Go Go Sushi" at 1 Post St., but is also not too chi-chi and expensive, and I think I've found it! 

I'll definitely be back :)
author: Karen F.

description:
This is not technically a 'new addition to the limited selection of sushi places by the Financial District area.' The exact location has been a sushi restaurant for a many years. It was Ginza for the last 3 or 4 years and Sake Bomb before that. And the quality of fish went down when it became Sushi Rock. 

As with many American sushi places, the nigiri pieces are cut too large. It's supposed to be one bite! If the texture of the fish is off and the piece is big, I find myself gagging to get it down. This happened with a piece of tai at Sushi Rock. Not enjoyable. The maguro was grainy too. We sat at the bar and asked what was good that day and were served mediocre fish. A good sushi chef will tell you if something isn't that great that day. A really good sushi chef (like Ted at Hamako) won't even buy the fish that day if it's not good.

I did enjoy their signature rolls immensely, but not sure each bite was worth $2. The mango spider roll rocked my world (ha ha ha) with the cold fruit on top of a warm roll with excellent lightly breaded tempura inside. I also had an excellent roll with white soybean paper instead of nori and tempura asparagus inside. But as with almost anything, if you deep fry it, it's good. 

Our bill was nearly twice what it would have been when the same place was Ginza, and it's not because it cost them anything to rennovate, because the only thing they did was add 2 TVs and put up their awning.

You'll love Sushi Rocks if you don't know much about good fish. And stick with rolls.
author: Laura B.

description:
i LOVE Sushi Rock, on POLK Street.

This one in Chitown though, is just not the same.  Not as tastey, not as fast, not as good of a setting.  The cable car rumble on my ass was a turn off.  Staff waiting and preparing aren't as 'with it' as Polk Street.  Totally different crowd too here vs. Polk.  However great price point as usual.

Go to Polk.  Go to Polk.
author: Leia K.

description:
All I can say is: Yelp should allow ZERO star.

Really awful nigiri.  Bad fish, weird cut, loose rice that didn't hold together.  The rice was not seasoned right either.  Too sour, too wet, horrible in sum.  So maybe this is more of a place for rolls?  OK, let's try that.  Wrong!  Rice fell apart before you put it in your mouth.  Ugly presentation.  Rough edges.  I can do a better job with my plastic sushi maker!  So maybe this is a place for the extended menu of soba, udon, and other rice dishes...?  Not true, either.  Horrible soba.  It tasted like frozen microwavable soba I bought from the supermarket in Taiwan.  Horrible tempura.  Worse than the Hawaiian version of shrimp tempura from L&L.

Maybe this is a place I should NEVER come back to?  Ditto.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
Alright, maybe its a faux-pas to get Japanese food in Chinatown, but this place was pretty good.  While enjoying the "Chinatown tourist experience" on a rainy day, this restaurant was a welcome spot to warm up, grab lunch, and talk with a friend.  

I wasn't super impressed with the decor, but the inside was clean and had some interesting art.  There was a TV along one wall and some simple artwork strategically placed.  A perk - there were large windows along 2 of the walls that took advantage of the corner views from it's 2nd story location over Grant St.  For someone like me who loves to people watch, this made for great lunchtime entertainment.  

The best part of my experience here - the moment we were seated the waitress dropped 2 bowls of miso soup and a salad in front of us (ie. heaven if you're been walking around in 45 degree rainy weather!).   The sushi was decent - my friend and I split several rolls including shrimp tempora and salmon/avaocado.  Everything tasted fresh and the presentation was typical for a Japanese restaurant (simple yet pleasing).  

The prices were very reasonable and the service was friendly.  I would argue that this place is definitely worth stopping by if you're in the area.
author: Angela Z.

description:
I enjoyed the rolls I had their rock n' roll.. and something else that escapes me. But yeah.. they were good. 

The Nigiri sushi.. BAD!

Their margarita... WORSE! Do not order this under any circumstances.
author: Claudia H.

description:
We were driving home from the Bloomie's preview day and decided to give this spot a try. We've been to the Polk St location before and figured this was their second location. We talked to the server and this spot was opened last two months ago and a third will be opening on Geary and 5th.
We ordered the mango and tuna sushi roll $14.95, pretty steep considering that it was a slice of tuna over rice and stuffed with mango and cucumber! They didn't even give an entire cube of mango but mixed it partially with cucumber.
We ordered a combo box to share (pick any three items) so we picked the salmon teriyaki, seabass teriyaki and chicken teriyaki. The box arrived and the presentation was somewhat lacking. The fishies and chicken were just tossed over beds of lettuce and cabbage in the three different columns. It might just be me but sometimes, presentation does matter to make it more edible and appealing. Oh well, the price tag for the box $11, seems a lot better deal than the mango tuna sushi. Overall, service was friendly, attentive and quick.
author: Yan M.

description:
I live close. I was on my way home with friends, and Sushi Rock was open. I felt like having some fish with beer, and they did, too, so we wandered in.

The best thing I can say about my experience here is, the sashimi came out in giant, filet-like slabs of meat. We were all stunned by its  inelegant, almost perverse enormity. Dig in.
